Þe deuil of hel I ȝow biteche! 738 R deuell, hell, yhow be teche.
And he wald haue forlayn my wif; 739 R forlayne, wyfe.
Þarfore sal na man saue his lyfe; 740 R þarfor sall no.
And to ded sal ȝe al be done, 741 R sall yhe all bi.
Þat better sold haue teched my son." 742 R suld, sone.
"Sir," said Maister Bausillas, 743 R Bansillas.
"Þat war grete wrang, to safe ȝoure grace. 744 R gret, saue yhour.
Al if þi son had wrethed þi wife, 745 R All, wyfe.
Wald þou þarfore lose his lyfe?" 746 R þarfor.
He said: "I fand my wife al rent, 747 R all.
Hir hare and hir face fowly shent; 748 R foully schent.
And whoso es funden hand-haueing, 749 R fonden hand haueyng.
It es no nede of witnesing." 750 R witnesyng.
Þe maister said: "Sir, no man sale
Sadly trow a stepmoders tale;
For þaire bolt es ful sone shot, 753 R þair, full, schote.
Titter to ill þan til gude note. 754 R till gud.
If þou for hir þi son so slase, 755 R þi son for hir.
On þe mun bifall swilk a case 756 R mon fall.
Als did vntil a gentil knight 757 R vntyll, gentell knyght.
For his grehund þat was wight." 758 R, A, E Of instead of For.
Þe Emperowre þat tale gan frayn, 759 R Emperour, frayne.
And þe maister sayd ogayn: 760 R said ogayne.
"Sir, whils þat I tel my tale 761 R tell.
Ȝowre son might suffer mekil bale; 762 R Yhour, myght, mykell.
Þan war my trauail al forlorn. 763 R all for lorne.
Þarfore do bring him vs biforn 764 R þarfor, bryng, bi forne.
And respite him for mi saying, 765 R respyte, my.
And ȝe sal here a wonder thing." 766 R yhe sall.
Þe Emperoure said: "Respite I him grant." 767 R Emperour, respyte, graunt.
And hastily went a sergant, 768 R sergeaunt.
And broght þe child into þe hall 769 R vn to.
Bifore his fader and þe knightes all. 770 R Bi for, knyghtes.
He lowted his fader and þam ilkane,
Bot wordes wald he speke nane.
Þe Emperoure said: "Maister Bawsillas, 773 R Emperour, Bansillas.
Tel now forth þi ferly case." 774 R Tell, furth.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Secund Tale, of Maister Bausillas. Heading R Bansillas. [Story II. Canis.]

LG.L: He said: "Sir, in þis same cete,
On a day of þe Trinite,
Was ordand to be a bowrdice 777 R ordaynd, bourdyse.
Of nobil knightes of mekil prise. 778 R noble knyghtes, mykell pryse.
In a medow þai made þaire play. 779 R mydow, þair.
And þus bifel on þat same day, 780 R bi fell.
Þe knight þat I of tel þis stownde, 781 R knyght, tell, stounde.
Had at hame a faire grehownde. 782 R fair grehounde.
Biside þe medow was his manere, 783 R Bisyde, mydow.
Al vmclosed with a reuere. 784 R All, ryuere.
Of ald werk was ilka wall,
Ful of creuices and holes ouer all. 786 R ffull, creuyces.
Þe knight had wed a faire lady; 787 R knyght, fair.
A faire childe sho haued him by. 788 R fair child scho.
Þare war thre norices it to ȝeme; 789 R þar, tre noryssches, yheme.
An gaf at sowke, als it wald seme; 790 R Ane, souke.
Þe toþer wasshes it and bathes, 791 R þe [or þat] obliterated, other wesches.
Makes þe bed, and dons þe clathes;
Þe thrid wasshes þe shetes oft, 793 R thred wesches.
And rokkes it on slepe soft.
"Þis grehund þat I are of talde 795 R grehound, tald.
Was wonder wight and þarto balde; 796 R þare to bald.
And þarto was he so wele taght, 797 R þare to.
Þe knight wald gif him for none aght. 798 R knyght, gyf.
Þe knight was armed in nobil wede, 799 R knyght, noble.
And sone lepe vp on his stede
With sheld on sholder and shaft in hand 801 R scheld, schulder, schaft.
To iust with knightes of þe land. 802 R knyghtes.
Sone he come into þe feld. 803 R felde.
Þe lady lay euer and byhelde, 804 R bi helde.
Vp in þe kastell on a vice, 805 R castell, vyce.
Whare sho might se þe faire bourdice. 806 R scho myght, fair bourdyse.
Þe norices said þat þai wald ga 807 R noryces.
For to se þe gamyn alswa; 808 R gamen all swa.
And al thre þai went out of þe hall 809 R all tre, MS. iii above line, perhaps in later hand.
And set þe credil vnder a wall. 810 R sett, credell.
Þe childe þarein slepand it lay. 811 R child.
Al thre þai went to se þe play 812 R All tre.
At a preue place bisyde. 813 R be syde.
And in þat time þus gan bitide: 814 R tyme, be tyde.
"A nedder was norist in þe wall, 815 R noryst.
And herd þe noys of riding all. 816 R rydeyng.
He loked out to se þat wonder,
And saw þe childe stand him vnder. 818 R child.
Vnto þe erth he went onane;
Þe childe he hopid to haue slane. 820 R child, hoped.
Þe grehund wanders þareobout, 821 R grehound wandres.
And sese how þe nedder crepis out; 822 R crepes.
And sone þan gan he him asail, 823 R assayle.
And toke him ful tite bi þe tayl. 824 R full tyte be, tayle.
And sone þe nedder bate him sare,
Þat he durst hald him na mare. 826 R no.
Out of his mowth when he was gane, 827 R mouthe.
Vnto þe credel he crepis onane; 828 R credell, crepes.
He fanded fast þe childe to styng. 829 R fandes, child.
Þe grehund ogayn to him gan flyng; 830 R grehound.
And sone he hentes [him] by þe bak, 831 MS. om. him, R bi.
And al obout his eres gan shak. 832 R all o bout, schak.
Bitwix þe nedder and þe grehownd 833 R grehound.
Þe credil weltered on þe grownd 834 R credell welterd, ground.
Vp so down with þaire fyghting, 835 R Vp sa doune, þair fyghtyng.
So þat þe childe lay grouelyng. 836 R child.
Þe foure stulpes held vp þe childe, 837 R four stolpes, child.
Þat he was nowþer hurt ne filde. 838 R nouther, fyld.
Þe nedder bate þe grehund sare, 839 R grehound.
Buth bak and side and eueraywhare. 840 R Both, syde.
Þe grehund bledes, þe nedder alswa; 841 R grehound, all swa.
Grete batail was bitwix þam twa. 842 R Gret.
"At þe last þe grehund þe neder slogh, 843 R grehound, nedder.
And al to peces he hym drogh. 844 R all, him.
By þai had done, withouten dout, 845 R Be.
Al was blody þam obout. 846 R All.
When þe bourdice was broght til ende, 847 R bourdyse, till.
Þe knightes wald no lenger lende, 848 R knyghtes, langer.
Bot ilka man his hernayse hent, 849 R hernays.
And hastily hame er þai went.
Þe norices went to hall in hy; 851 R noryces.
And ful sone þai war sary: 852 R full.
Þe credel with þe childe þai fand; 853 R credell, child.
Turned on þe stulpes þai saw it stand.
Þai wend þe childe ware ded for ay, 855 R child war.
Þarfore þai luked noght how it lay; 856 R þarfor.
Al obout þare saw þai blode. 857 R All.
Þai had slike wa þai wex nere wode; 858 R slyke.
Grete sorow had þai in þaire hert. 859 R Gret, þair.
Þe grehund cried, so euyl him smert; 860 R grehound cryed, euell.
Þai wend he had bene wode and wilde, 861 R wyld.
And in his wodnes slane þe childe. 862 R wodenes, child.
Þe lady oft in swown gan fall 863 R swoun.
Euin omang þam in þe hall. 864 R Euen.
'Allas,' sho said, 'þat I was born! 865 R scho sayd.
Es my faire childe now fra me lorn?' 866 R fair child.
Þe knight hame come in þat tyde, 867 R knyght.
And his men on ilka side; 868 R syde.
He sese þam wepe and sorow make,
Ilkane for þe childes sake;
Þe knight þam asked what þam was, 871 R knyght, þan for þam, þat for þam, MS. hat of what obliterated.
And son þai tald him al þe cas. 872 R sone, all, case.
"Þe lady said: 'Sir, þi grehunde 873 R grehounde.
Has etin oure childe on þis grownde. 874 R eten our child, grounde.
Bot if þou reue him sone his life, 875 R lyfe.
Miself I sal sla with my knyfe.' 876 R sall.
Þe knight went withowten let; 877 R knyght, with outen lett.
His fayre grehund sone him met; 878 R fair grehound, mett.
He ran obout both here and þare,
And berked fast, so felde he sare; 880 R barkett, feld.
Of rinyng might he haue no rest: 881 R rynyng myght.
Þe nedder had venum on him kest;
He fawned his lord fast with his tail. 883 R tayle.
And þe knyght, for he wald noght fayl, 884 R fayle.
With his swerd on þe rig he hittes, 885 R ryg, hyttes.
And sone in sonder he him slittes. 886 R slyttes.
Þe grehund es ded in þat place. 887 R grehound.
Þe knight vnto þe credil gase; 888 R knyght, credell.
Ay lay þe childe fast slepeand, 889 R child, slepand.
And þe wemen sare wepeand. 890 R wepand.
Þe knyght findes þe nedder ded, 891 R fyndes, dede.
In peces casten in þat stede;
Þe credil was blody and þe grund 893 R credell, bludy, ground.
Of þe nedder and þe grehund. 894 R grehound.
Þe credel es turned, þe child es quik; 895 R credell, quyk.
Þareof haue þai grete ferlik. 896 R gret ferlyk.
He sese þe hund þe nedder slogh;
Þan þe knight had sorow inogh; 898 R knyght.
Ful grete greuance to him bigan. 899 R gret, tyll for to, bygan.
He said: 'Sorow cum to þat man, 900 R com.
And sertanly right so it sale, 901 R sertainly ryght.
Þat euer trowes any womans tale. 902 R wemens.
Allas,' he said, 'for so did I!' 903 R sayd, dyd.
Þarwith he murned and made grete cri. 904 R gret cry.
He kald his menȝe les and mare, 905 R cald, menyhe.
And shewed þam his sorow sare, 906 R schewed.
How his childe was hale and sownde, 907 R child, sounde.
And slane was his gude grehound 908 R gre∣hounde.
For his prowes and his gude dede, 909 R gud.
And also for his wiues rede. 910 R all so, wyves.
"'A!' he said, 'sen I þe slogh,
I miself sal by þe wogh; 912 R mi self sall bi.
I sal ken oþer knightes, sanz fail, 913 R sall, knyghtes, faile.
To trow noght in þaire wife counsail.' 914 R þair, counsaile.
He set him down þare in þat thraw, 915 R sett, doune.
And gert a grome his gere of draw;
Al his gay gere he gaf him fra, 917 R All.
And al barfote forth gan he ga, 918 R all bare fote furth.
Withowten leue of wife or childe. 919 R with outen, child.
He went into þe woddes wilde, 920 R wild.
And to þe forest fra al men, 921 R fro all.
Þat nane sold of his sorow ken. 922 R suld.
Þare tholed he mani a sari stownde 923 R many, sary stounde.
For sorow of his gude grehownde; 924 R gud grehounde.
And for þe kounsail of his wife 925 R counsail, wyfe.
In sorow þus he led his life. 926 R lyfe.
"So mai þou haue, Sir Emperoure, 927 R may.
Sorow, and shame, and dishonoure, 928 R schame.
To sla þi son ogains þe right, 929 R ogayns, ryght.
Als þe grehund was with þe knyght; 930 R grehound.
For he was fel and ouer hastif, 931 R fell, hastyfe.
And wroght by kounsayl of his whif." 932 R counsail, wyfe.
Þe Emperoure [sware]: "By Ihesu fre, 933 R Emperour, MS. om. sware, R bi.
So sal noght bifal to me! 934 R sall, bi fall of me.
And, maister, I hete þe hardily,
Þis day sal noght my son dy." 936 R sall.
"Sir," said Maister Bausillas, 937 R Bansillas.
"Trowes my kownsail in þis cas; 938 R coun∣sail, case.
For al þis werld wil þe despise, 939 R all, world will, despyse.
To trow þi whif and leue þe wise." 940 R wife, wyse.
Þe Emperowre said: "Þat ware reson; 941 MS. roson, R Emperowr, war resone.
I sal noght by hir kownsayl done." 942 R sall, be, cownsail.
Þe childe ogayn to preson es sent; 943 R child.
Þe court departes, þe maister es went.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bigins þe Thrid Proces. Heading R bigyns, thred process.

LG.L: When al war parted out of þat place, 945 R all.
Þe Emperoure to chamber gase. 946 R Emperour, chaumbre.
Þare he findes his lady; 947 R fyndes.
Sho sobbed and sighed ful sarily. 948 R Scho, syghed full saryly.
"Whannow," he said, "dame, ertow wrath?" 949 R wrathe.
"Ȝa, sertes," sho sayd, and sware grete ath. 950 R Yha, scho said, gret athe.
He said: "Dame, tel me who þe greues." 951 R tell.
Sho said: "Þat lad þat ouer lang lifes, 952 R Scho, lyfes.
Þat þou calles þine owin sone. 953 R awen.
To euil ded might he be done! 954 R euell, myght.
Bot if þou of him tak vengance, 955 R vengaunce.
Of þe sal fal swilk a chance, 956 R On instead of Of, sall fall, chaunce.
He wil þe bring to swilk ending 957 R will, bryng, endyng.
Als þe wilde bare had with clowing." 958 R wyld, clowyng.
Þe Emperoure said: "Dame, tel me mare, 959 R Emperour, tell.
How it was of þe wild bare." 960 R wyld.
"Sir," sho said, "gladly I will, 961 R scho.
Bot luke ȝe tak gude tent þartill." 962 R yhe, gud, þare tyll.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Thrid Tale Tald þe Wyfe. Heading R thred. [Story III. Aper.]

LG.L: "Sir, a litel here by west 963 R lytell, bi.
Was sumtime a faire forest. 964 R som tyme, fair.
A wilde bare was bred þarin 965 R wild, þare ine.
Fra a gryse til a grete swyn. 966 R gryss tyll, gret swyne.
Na man dorst walk in þat forest 967 R No, durst, foreste.
For ferdnes of þat wilde beste. 968 R wild.
In middes þe forest was a playn; 969 R myddes, playne.
Þare stode a tre of hawes sertayn; 970 R sertayne.
Faire and rede and ripe þai ware. 971 R ffair, rype.
Þeder was wont þe wilde bare; 972 R þider, wyld.
Ilka day he went þartill, 973 R þare tyll.
Vnder þe tre to ete his fill. 974 R ett, fyll.
"Bifel þus in þat somer tide, 975 R Bi fell, tyde.
A hird ȝemed bestes þar biside; 976 R hyrd yhemed, þare bi syde.
A beste fra him was raiked oway. 977 R fro, rayked.
He went to seke it al a day, 978 R all.
And by þis tre of hawes he come. 979 R bi.
Of þam he toke, for he had tome;
In his hode he gederd þare;
And in þat cumes þe wilde bare. 982 R comes, wild.
When þe hird him saw, he was ful rad; 983 R hyrd, full.
He might noght fle, so was he stad; 984 R myght.
Into þe tre he clymbes on high, 985 R klymbes, hegh.
And þe bare þan come him negh.
Hawes findes he ferly fone 987 R fyndes.
Forby he was won to done; 988 R ffor bi.
He loked vp and saw þe hird; 989 R luked, hyrd.
Stil he sat and noght he stird. 990 R Styll, satt, styrd.
"Þe bare for tene þan whet his tuskes,
And wrot þe erth vp al in buskes; 992 R wrott, all.
Out of his mowth þe fame was white.
Vnto þe tre fast gan he smite; 994 R smyte.
Þe tre wagged als it wald fall;
Þan was þe hirdman ferd at all. 996 R hyrd man.
Bot sone he fand a medcine gode: 997 R medsyn gude.
His hand he put tite in his hode, 998 R tyte.
And kastes down fast of þe hawes. 999 R doune.
Þan þe bare on þe grund gnawes; 1000 R ground.
And when his wambe was filled wele, 1001 R wamb, fyld.
On his knese þan gan he knele.
And son percayued þe hirdman 1003 R sone persayued, hyrd man.
Þat þe bare to fall bygan; 1004 R bi gan.
He castes him down hawes inogh, 1005 R kastes, doune.
And cumes himself down by a bogh. 1006 R comes, doune bi.
By þe left hand he hinges þare, 1007 R Bi, hynges.
And with þe right hand he clowes þe bare. 1008 R ryght, klowes, R om. hand.
Fast he rubed him on þe rig, 1009 R rubbed, ryg.
And þe bare bigins to lyg. 1010 R bi gyns.
"Seþin he clowed him on þe wambe, 1011 R Sithen.
And he lay doun meke als a lambe; 1012 R doune.
He closed his yen als he wald slepe, 1013 R eghen.
And þe hird þan toke gude kepe: 1014 R hyrd, gud.
Preuely he drogh his knife, 1015 R knyfe.
And reft þe wilde bare his life. 1016 R wild, lyfe.
Al if he wild and wighter ware, 1017 R All, wyld.
Þe hirdman þus has slane þe bare; 1018 R hyrd man.
He lete him ly and went his way.
Sir Emperoure, by þe I say, 1020 R Emperour.
Þou ert þe bare, þe maisters þe clowes;
With þaire fals tales, þat þou trowes, 1022 R þair.
Þai sal so counsail þe and rede 1023 R sall.
Til þai haue broght þe to þi ded." 1024 R Till, dede.
He said: "I wate by wham þou menes, 1025 R be.
Bot it sal noght be als þou wenes; 1026 R sall.
For sertes, dame, arly tomorow 1027 R arely.
Sal my son be ded, with sorow!" 1028 R Sall.
"Sir," sho said, "þan dose þou right." 1029 R scho, ryght.
Þus þai passed ouer þat night, 1030 R nyght.
And sleped till þe dai gan spring. 1031 R tyll, day, spryng.
Þe thrid tale þus mase ending. 1032 R thred, endyng.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bygyns þe Ferth Proces. Heading MS. iiii., R bigyns, process.

LG.L: Þe day es cumen, þe night es gane; 1033 R þ of þe illegible, comen, nyght.
Þe Emperoure rase sone onane. 1034 R Emperour rayse.
Þai opind ȝates of þe palays, 1035 R opend yhates.
And in come knightes and buriase. 1036 R knyghtes.
When þai war cumen into þe toure, 1037 R comen.
Omang þam come þe Emperowre. 1038 R Emperoure.
His turmentoure sone gert he call,
Bad bring his sone forth into hall; 1040 R bryng, furth into þe hall.
He did his lordes biding biliue. 1041 R dyd, bydyng bi lyue.
Omang þam þan was mekil striue; 1042 R mykell stryue.
For þe Emperoure was so boun 1043 R boune.
To sla his son ogayns resoun; 1044 R resoune.
He wald spare him for nothing,
Bot gert do of al his clething, 1046 R all.
And bad þam bete him in þat tide 1047 R tyde.
Til blode brast out on ilka side. 1048 R Till, syde.
He bad, when he was sogat bet, 1049 R so gate bett.
Þai sold him hang on a gebet, 1050 R suld, gebett.
And þat þai sold let for nothing. 1051 R at instead of þat, suld lett.
Þan led þai him forth for to hing. 1052 R furth, hyng.
Þai led him thurgh þat riche cete; 1053 R ryche.
Of his pain was grete pete. 1054 R payn, gret.
Mani men of grete renown 1055 R Many, gret renoune.
Folowd him out of þe toun; 1056 R toune.
And al þai made grete noys and cri, 1057 R all, gret, cry.
And said with wrang þat he sold dy. 1058 R suld.
And right omang þam in þe prese 1059 R ryght.
Come ridand Maister Anxilles, 1060 R rydeand.
Þat an of his Seuyn Maisters was; 1061 R ane, seuen.
For his decipil he said "Allas!" 1062 R disciple.
Þe puple cried to him in fere: 1063 R pople cryed.
"Maister, help now þi scolere."
Þe maister rides fast fra þam all, 1065 R rydes.
And hies to þe Emperowres hall. 1066 R hyes fast to þe emperours.
Þare he findes þe Emperowre; 1067 R fyndes, Emperoure.
He gretes him with grete honowre. 1068 R gret honoure.
Þe Emperoure answers with ill, 1069 R Emperour.
And þus he said þe mayster vntill: 1070 R sayd, maister vntyll.
"Mekil mawgre mot þou haue 1071 R Mykell.
For þe teching of my knaue; 1072 R techyng.
Ȝe haue serued litil mede, 1073 R Yhe, lytell.
And so sal ȝe haue for ȝowre dede." 1074 R sall yhe, yhour.
Þe maister said: "Emperoure of prise, 1075 R Emperour, pryse.
Ȝe war won to be war and wise; 1076 R Yhe, wyse.
Nowþer sold ȝe bete ne ban 1077 R Nouther suld yhe.
For þe wordes of a woman;
For wemen wil be ligh[t]ly wrath, 1079 MS. lighly, R will, lyghtly wrathe.
And cownsail comunly to skath. 1080 R counsail comonly, skathe.
Ȝe sold noght sla ȝowre son forthi, 1081 R Yhe suld, yhour.
Bot if ȝe wist he war worthi. 1082 R yhe, worthy.
If ȝe him sla and vs al seuyn, 1083 R yhe, all seuen.
I pray to Ihesu Crist in heuyn 1084 R heuen.
Þat vnto ȝow mot fal slike case 1085 R yhow, fall slyke.
Als did to Maister Ypocrase, 1086 R dyd.
Þat slogh his neuow for his lare."
Þe Emperoure said: "Tel me mare." 1088 R Emperour, sir tell.
Þe maister answerd wordes milde: 1089 R myld.
"Sir, and þou wil saue þi childe, 1090 R will, child.
And gif him respite al þis day, 1091 R gyf, respyte all.
Þan þe soth I sal þe say 1092 R sall.
Of Ypocras and his neuow." 1093 R Ypocrase.
Þe Emperoure said: "I grant him trew." 1094 R Emperour, graunt.
Efter þe childe sone war þai boun, 1095 R boune.
To put him ogayn to presown. 1096 R ogayne, presoune.
Bot first þai broght him to þe towre, 1097 R trowr.
Bifore his fader, þe Emperowre. 1098 R Bi for, Emperoure.
Þare gederd al þe cownsail hale, 1099 R all, counsail.
And þe maister bigan hys tale. 1100 R his.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Ferth Tale Sayd Mayster Anxilles. [Story IV. Medicus.]

LG.L: "Syr," he said, "somtym it was 1101 R Sir, sayd som tyme.
A grete clerk þat hight Ypocras. 1102 R gret, ypocrase.
Of sotelte might none be slike, 1103 R myght, slyke.
Ne of lechecraft was none him like. 1104 R lyke.
With him was dweland his neuow 1105 R dwelland.
For to lere of his vertu. 1106 R vertow.
Þe childe was ful sharp of wit; 1107 R child, full scharp, witt.
Al þat he saw sone lerid he it. 1108 R All, lered.
Ypocrase percayued hys lare, 1109 R persayued his.
And thoght he wald shew him na mare; 1110 R schew, no.
For wele he trowed, on euyn and morn, 1111 R euen, morne.
Þat þe childe sold pas him byforn. 1112 R child suld, bi forne.
Þe child percayued his emes will, 1113 R chyld persayued.
And wroght al preuely and styll, 1114 R all.
Vntil he kowth al þe maistri; 1115 R vn tyll, couth all, maistry.
Ypocras was ful wrath forþi. 1116 Ipocrase, Ipo∣crase, full.
"In þat time bifel þis thing: 1117 R tyme be fell.
Of Hungery þe riche king 1118 R ryche kyng.
Had a son þat ful seke was, 1119 R full.
And he sent efter Maister Ypocras, 1120 R om. he (perhaps an erasure), ypocrase.
And had him com his son to hele,
And he sold gif him florines fele. 1122 R suld gyf, florance.
Ypocras thoght lath to gane; 1123 R Ypocrase, lathe.
He calles his neuow sone onane,
And bides him wend vnto þat land 1125 R byddes.
To tak þe king son vnder hand: 1126 R kyng.
'If þou can do him no medcine, 1127 R kan, medcyne.
Þan sal I send him som of myne.' 1128 R sall.
Þai ordand þe childe a gude palfray;
On he strides and wendes his way. 1130 R And on, strydes.
Wen he was cumen bifore þe king, 1131 R When, comen bi for, kyng.
Vnto his son he gan him bring; 1132 R bryng.
And sone when þat he saw þe childe, 1133 R child.
He spak vnto him wordes milde. 1134 R myld.
He tastes þe child syn and vayne,
And says he suffers mekil payne. 1136 R suffirs mikell.
"Þan þe leche askes a glas; 1138 R Ane vrynall.
An vrinal sone broght him was.
Þe child made water als þai him kend;
Þe leche loked what might him mend. 1140 R luked.
In þe water he saw, sanz fail, 1141 R fayle.
Þe child was geten out of sposail. 1142 R sposaile.
Vnto him þan he cald þe quene,
And said: 'Madame, tel vs bitwene 1144 R tell.
Wha has getin þis child of þe; 1145 R geten, chid.
On al manere wit bus me.' 1146 R all, witt.
Sho said: 'Nane oþer bot þe king.' 1147 R Scho, none, kyng.
'Madame,' he said, 'þat es gabing; 1148 R gabyng.
He was neuer cumen of kynges strene.' 1149 R comen.
Sho said: 'Lat al slike wordes bene,
Or sertes I sal ger bete þe so 1151 R sall, MS. þe above line (pale, perhaps a later hand).
Þat þou sal neuer ride ne go.' 1152 R sall, ryde.
"'Madame,' he said, 'so mot I the,
So may noght þi son heled be;
Þu most tel me al þe case 1155 R tell, all.
How þat þis childe getin was. 1156 R child geten wase.
Sertes, dame, it most be so,
Or els þi son sal neuer go. 1158 R sall.
I mai do þi childe na bote 1159 R may, child no.
Bot if þou tel me crop and rote.' 1160 R tell, cropp.
"Þe quene said: 'Sen it most be so,
Þou most tel it til na mo; 1162 R tell, to no.
For and my kounsail war vndone, 1163 R counsail.
Sertes I mund be shent ful sone.' 1164 R mond, schent full.
'Dame, by ded þat I sal degh, 1165 R bi þe ded, sall.
I sal neuer more þe wregh.' 1166 R sall.
'Sir,' sho said, 'so it bifell, 1167 R scho.
Þis es þe twe[l]ft ȝere in Auerell, 1168 MS. tweft, R yhere.
Þe Eril of Nauern hider gan ride, 1169 R Erell, hyder, ryde.
With mani knightes and mekil pride, 1170 R many knyghtes, mykell pryde.
With my lord him for to play;
And here he dwelled moni a day. 1172 R many.
And sone bigan I him to loue
More þan ani þe erth oboue; 1174 R any.
For grete luf and for gude drewri, 1175 R gret, gud drewry.
I let þe Erl so lig me by. 1176 R lete, Erell, lyg.
Þusgat was þis ilk child getin; 1177 R þusgate, geten.
Bot I prai þe þat no man weten.' 1178 R pray, wyten.
"'Nai, dame,' he said, 'bot wiltou here? 1179 R Nay, sayd, will þou.
For þe child was geten on þis manere,
To medcin bus him drink and ete 1181 R medcyn, drynk.
Contrariouse drink, contrarius mete; 1182 R Contrarius drynk.
Him bihoues on þis wise do:
Ete beres fless and drink þe bro.' 1184 R Ette, flessch, drynk.
Þai toke a bere þare in þe town,
And sethed it in a kalderowne. 1186 R kalderoune.
Þai gaf þe childe þareof to ete, 1186 R kalderoune.
Ilk day omang his oþer mete. 1187 R child.
Þe bro he drank also with wyne,
And sone amended bi þis medcine. 1190 R medcyne.
When he was warist faire and wele, 1191 R waryst fair.
Þe king gaf him mani faire iuel 1192 R kyng, many fair iuele.
Vnto þe leche, and siluer and golde 1193 R both instead of first and, syluer, gold.
Als mekil als he tak wolde. 1194 R mykell, wold.
"Hame ogayn he went ful sone 1195 R ogayne, full.
And tald his mayster how he had done. 1196 R maister.
Ypocras asked if al war wele; 1197 R Ypocrase, all.
'Ȝa, sir,' he said, 'als haue I sele.' 1198 R Yha.
He asked what was þe childes medcine; 1199 R medcyne.
'Beres fless,' he said, 'and þe bro with wine.' 1200 R flessch, wyne.
'Þan was he horkop,' said Ypocras. 1201 R horcopp, ypocrase.
'Sir,' said þe child, 'I trow he was.' 1202 R wase.
'O son,' he said, 'bi Goddes dome, 1203 R godes.
Þou ert waxen a wel wise grome!' 1204 R well.
Þan Ipocras thinkes how he myght 1205 R Ypocrase thynkes.
Sla his neuow ogains þe right. 1206 R ogayns, ryght.
"Son þareefter on a day 1207 R Sone.
To feldes þai went þam for to play;
Vntil a gardine gan þai gane 1209 R vntyll, gardyne.
Whare nobil herbes war many ane. 1210 R noble erbes.
Ypocras said to his neuow: 1211 R Ypo∣crase.
'Here er herbes of grete vertu.' 1212 R gret vertow.
Þe child gaf ane to Ypocras, 1213 R ypocrase.
And he said fele better þar was; 1214 R om. he, R þare wase.
And so he said bot to asay 1215 R assay.
How he might þe childe bitray. 1216 R myght, child.
Anoþer herb þe child has found, 1217 R Ane other herbe, founde.
And doun he stowpes vnto þe grownd, 1218 R doune, grounde.
Þat nobil herb vp for to tane. 1219 R noble erbe.
Ypocras him strake in þe rig-bane; 1220 R Ypocrase, ryg bane.
Þe childe fel down and might noght stand. 1221 R child fell doune, myght.
Þus his eme slogh him with his hand.
He beried him right sone in hy, 1223 R biryed, ryght.
And said þat he died sodanly. 1224 R dyed sodainly.
"Bot God, þat es of heuyn king, 1225 R heuen kyng.
Þat ouersese erth and alkins thing, 1226 R alkyns thyng.
Tok vengance on þis tresown, 1227 R Toke, tresoune.
And sent Ypocras þe menisowne. 1228 R ypocrase, menysoune.
Þan wist wele Maister Ypocras 1229 R ypocrase.
Þat he sold dy for þis trispase; 1230 R suld.
For al medcines þat he kowth teche, 1231 R all medcyns, couth.
His menyson he might noght leche, 1232 R meny∣sone, myght.
Himseluyn might he mend no dele. 1233 R Him seluen myght.
And, for he wald men wist þis wele,
A tome wineton forth gert he set, 1235 R wyne ton furth, sett.
And ful of water he did it ȝet; 1236 R full, dyd, yhett.
And hastili he sent þat tide 1237 R hastily, tyde.
Efter his neghburs on ilka side. 1238 R syde.
He tald bifore þam euerilkane 1239 R bi for, a dele deleted before ane.
How he had his neuow slane;
'And sertes for I wroght þat ill,
Es þis vengance cumen me till.' 1242 R comen, tyll.
In þe tun he bored holes ful fele, 1243 R full.
And stopped ilkane with a dosele.
"Þan he enoynt þe holes obout,
And seþen he drogh þe dosels out; 1246 R sythen.
And water of þe ton come nane. 1247 R om. And.
Hereof meruayled mani ane. 1248 R þar of meruaild many.
'Lo,' he said, 'I can ger stem 1249 R kan, steme.
Þe water wele, withowten wem; 1250 R with outen weme.
Bot I can noght, bi no resown, 1251 R kan, be, resoune.
Sese miself of þe menisown. 1252 R my self, menysoune.
And vnto me es cumen þis wogh 1253 R comen.
For my neuow þat I slogh;
And I had none encheson why, 1255 R enchesoune whi.
Bot for he was wiser þan I.
Now es nane mai salue my sare 1257 R may.
Bot if þat he now lifand ware.' 1258 R lyfand.
"Sir," said þe maister, "þus it wase
Of þe wise man Ypocras; 1260 R ypocrase.
Þus ended he with sorow inogh, 1261 R I noghe.
For þat he his neuow slogh, 1262 R sloghe.
Þat vnto him had trispast noght.
Þe same, sir, sal to þe be wroght 1264 R sall.
If þou so smertly slas þi sone 1265 R sla.
And wate noght what he haues il done. 1266 R ill.
Þarfore, sir, do him alegance." 1267 R þarfor, aleggance.
Þe Emperoure als sone him grantes. 1268 R Emperour al sone, grauntes.
Þe maister takes his leue and gase.
Þe firth tale þus ending mase. 1270 R ferth, endyng.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bigins þe Fift Proces. Heading R bigyns, fyft process, MS. v.

LG.L: Þe mayster hame ogayn es gane; 1271 R ogayne.
Þe Emperoure wendes to chameber onane. 1272 R Emperour, chaumber o .... .
Þe Emperice byfore he fand; 1273 R bi fore.
Wepid fast and wrang hyr hand. 1274 R Wepand, hir.
Þe Emperoure said: "Dame, for þe rode,
Mak meri and amend þi mode, 1276 R mery.
And tel me wha haues done þe wrang; 1277 R tell.
I sal þe venge or euer I gang." 1278 R sall.
Sho said: "Sir, meruayl es it nane;
I se þine honore es nere gane; 1279-80 R om.
Þe wede I se wax ouer þe corn; 1281 R waxes, corne.
Allas, þat I in werld was born! 1282 R world, borne.
Allas, þat I þat dai sold sene 1283 R day suld.
Þat we sold departed bene!" 1284 R suld.
"Dame," said þe Emperoure, "how swa? 1285 R Emperour.
Sal we part now son in twa?" 1286 R Sall, sone.
"Ȝa, sertes," sho said, "þat sal þou se; 1287 R Yha, scho, sall yhe.
For þou wil noght wirk efter me, 1288 R yhe will.
Hastily þou bese vndone
By him þat þou cals þi son. 1290 R Bi, calles, sone.
For his sake bath knight and swayn 1291 R knyght, swayne.
Sal al be turned þe ogayn; 1292 R Sall all, ogayne.
And hastly sal þai put þe downe 1293 R hastily sall, putt, doune.
Out of þi realme and þi renowne, 1294 R renoune.
And set þi son vp in þi stede; 1295 R sett.
And sertes me war leuer to be ded. 1296 R dede.
And if þou lat it sogat be, 1297 R sogate.
I prai to God it fal of þe 1298 R pray, fall.
Als it was sene for sertayne
Of him þat with his son was slayn: 1300 R slayne.
Þe son þe fader heuid of smate." 1301 R heued.
"Dame," he said, "what was he þat?" 1302 R þate.
"Sir," sho said, "if I þe tell, 1303 R scho.
Þou settes nothing bi my spell; 1304 R be.
And sertanly þat sal þe rew." 1305 R sertainly, sall.
"Dame," he said, "by dere Ihesu, 1306 R be.
I sal tomorn wirk al þi will; 1307 R sall, all.
And þarfore tel þis tale me till, 1308 R tell, tyll.
Fully al how it byfell." 1309 R all, bi fell.
Þe Emperise hir tale gan tell. 1310 R Emperice.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Fift Tale Sayd Þe Wyfe. Heading R fyft, said. [Story V. Gaza.]

LG.L: Sho said: "Sir, sen þis town bigan, 1311 R Scho, toune.
Here was wonand a nobil man. 1312 R noble.
Of him was word in ilk cuntre, 1313 R contre.
For no man was so riche als he; 1314 R ryche.
Emperoure he was of nobil fame, 1315 R Emperour, noble.
And Octouian was his name. 1316 R Octouyane.
He gert mak a ful nobil toure, 1317 R full noble.
And þarin did he his tresoure. 1318 R þare in dyd.
In Rome þan was wise klerkes twa. 1319 R wyse clerkes.
A liberal man was ane of þa; 1320 R lyberall.
Þe toþer was hard and fast haldand,—
Nothing wald he gif with his hand. 1322 R wold, gyf, MS. his above line.
Þarfore þe Emperowre him toke 1323 R þarfor, emperour.
To kepe his tresore, als tels þe boke. 1324 R telles, buke.
He keped it wele by night and day, 1325 R bi nyght.
For wele he hoped it sold last ay. 1326 R suld.
"Þe large clerk wist al ful right. 1327 R all full ryght.
And efterward, opon a night, 1328 R nyght.
Vntil ane of his sons said he: 1329 R vn tyll.
'Rise vp, felow, and wend with me.' 1330 R Ryse.
Þe child said: 'Sir, at ȝowre will.' 1331 R yhour.
Forth went þai preuely and still. 1332 R styll.
Þai toke with þam bath hak and spade; 1333 R both.
Vnder þe erth a hole þai made 1334 R vndor.
Right into þat nobil towre. 1335 R Ryght, noble toure.
Þe fader went in to feche tresoure; 1336 R fech.
He findes a bag ful of mone; 1337 R fyndes, full.
In bath his handes þat hentes he,
And til þe hole sone he it gat. 1339 R till, gatt.
His son keped it right þarat. 1340 R þare att.
Þan þe fader come forth ogayne, 1341 R furth.
And dited þe hole euyn and playn. 1342 R dytted, euen, playne.
Hame with þe tresore hied þai fast, 1343 R hyed.
And made meri wils it last. 1344 R mery whils.
"Sone efter þe kaytef senatoure 1345 R kaytyf.
Gase to loke his lord tresoure. 1346 R luke.
Þe hole he findes stoped with a stane; 1347 R fyndes stopped.
Þe mekil bag oway was tane. 1348 R mykell.
His wa he wald tel to na man; 1349 R tell, no.
Bot in his hert he thinkes þan
Þat he þat þe hole so left
Ogain þeder wald cum eft; 1352 R Ogayn þider, com.
And þan he thoght þam for to swike. 1353 R swyke.
Þare gert he mak a ful depe dike, 1354 R make, full, dyke.
Vnder þe wall, þat was so thik; 1355 R thyk.
And filled it ful of ter and pik, 1356 R fyld, full, terr, pyk.
Þat if þe thef come þeder ogain, 1357 R thefe com þider o gayne.
In þe dike he sold be slayne. 1358 R dyke, suld, slane.
And efter þat ilk day arly 1359 R arely.
Went he to þe tresory,
To loke if þat his gest war cumen 1361 R luke, comen.
Þat þe tresore þeþin had nomen. 1362 R þethen.
"Al had þai spended sone sertayn; 1363 R All, sertayne.
Þe fader and þe son wendes ogayn. 1364 R ogayne.
Bitwene þam toke þai out þe stane;
Þe fader crepis in sone onane, 1366 R crepes.
And doun he fals in ter and pik,— 1367 R doune, falles, terr, pyk.
Wit ȝe wele, þat was ful wik. 1368 R Witt yhe, full.
Loud he cried and said "Allas!" 1369 R cryed.
His son askes him how it was. 1370 R om. son.
He said: 'I stand vp til þe chin 1371 R to, chyn.
In pik, þat I mun neuer out win.' 1372 R pyk, mon, wyn.
'Allas,' said þe son, 'what sal I do?' 1373 R sall.
He said: 'Tak my swerd þe vnto,
And smite my heuid fra my body.' 1375 R smyte, heued fro.
Þe son said: 'Nai, sir, sekerly; 1376 R nay, sikerly.
Are I sold myseluen sla.' 1377 R suld.
'Son,' he said, 'it most be swa,
Or els þou and al þi kyn 1379 R all.
Mun be shent, bath mare and myn; 1380 R Mon, schent both more, myne.
And if mi heuid be smeten oway, 1381 R my heued, smyten.
Na word sal men of me say. 1382 R sall.
Þarfore, son, for mi benisown, 1383 R þarfor, benysoune.
Smite of my heuid, and wend to town, 1384 R Smyte, heued, toune.
And hide it in som preue pit, 1385 R hyde, pytt.
So þat na man mai knaw it.' 1386 R no, may, itt.
"His fader heuid of smate he þare, 1387 R heued.
And forth with him oway it bare. 1388 R furth.
Wele he thoght it for to hide, 1389 R hyde.
For shame þat efter might bitide; 1390 R schame, myght be tyde.
For if men wist, it wald be wer, 1391 R war.
And lath him was to bere it fer.
"Als he went biside a gang, 1393 R bi syde.
Into þe pit þe heuid he slang. 1394 R pytt, heued.
Þan went he hame wightli and sone, 1395 R wightly.
And tald his moder how he had done.
Þe whif weped, so was her wa; 1397 R wife, hir.
So did his breþer and sisters alswa. 1398 R systers.
On þe morn þe senatoure
Went arly vnto þe toure; 1400 R arely.
In þe pit he findes a hedles man, 1401 R pytt, fyndes.
Bot knaw him for nothin[g] he can. 1402 MS. no thin, R kan.
He kowth noght ken þan his felaw 1403 R couth.
Þat he wont ful wele to knaw. 1404 R he was wont full.
He gert haue of þe pik bidene, 1405 R pyk.
And wass þe body faire and clene. 1406 R wasch, fair.
He loked byfore þan and bihind; 1407 R bi fore, bi hynd.
Knawlageing kowth he none find. 1408 R knawlegyng couth, fynd.
"Þan gert he bring twa stalworth hors, 1409 R bryng.
And bad þam draw þe hedeles cors; 1410 R hedles.
And whoso þai saw sorow make,
He bad biliue þai sold þam take, 1412 R bi lyue, suld.
And at þai war to preson led,
For þai er al his awin kinred. 1414 R all, awen kynred.
Þat hedles body by þe fete 1415 R bi.
Was drawen in Rome thorgh ilka strete, 1416 R thurgh.
Vntil þai come bifor þe dore 1417 R vn tyll, be for.
Whare þe ded man wond bifore;
Þare þai murned and made il chere, 1419 R ill.
Whif and childer, al in fere. 1420 R Wife, all.
Þe seriantes toke þarto gude kepe, 1421 R tuk, gud.
Þam for to tak þat þai saw wepe.
Þe childer þan war sare adred;
'Allas,' þai said, 'now er we ded!'
"Þe son, þat wist of al þe care, 1425 R all.
Hirt himseluen wonder sare;
He smate himseluen in þe cheke;
Þaire sorow sone so gan þai eke. 1428 R þair.
Þai tald to þam þat wald þam take,
Þat þai wepid for þaire broþer sake. 1430 R weped, þair.
Þai shewed þe wonde of þaire broþer, 1431 R schewed, wound, þare.
And said þai wepid for nane oþer. 1432 R sayd.
Þe seriantes saw þe wound sertain; 1433 R sertaine.
Þai trowed þam wele and turned ogain. 1434 R ogayne.
"Lo, sir," sho said, "here may þou see 1435 R scho.
How þi son wald do with þe.
Þe childe was his wit bireuid, 1437 R child, witt bi reued.
When he kest his fader heuid 1438 R heued.
Intil a gang, so ful of fen, 1439 R Intyll, full.
And wald noght in erth hide it þen, 1440 R hyde.
Preueli, als he wele myght." 1441 R Preuely.
"Dame," he said, "þou sais ful right; 1442 R full ryght.
Vnkind vntil his fader he was." 1443 R vnkynd vn tyll, wase.
"Sir, on þe mot fal swilk case 1444 R fall slyke.
Bi þi son,—þe deuil him hang 1445 R deuell.
Bot he kast þi heuid in a gang!" 1446 R heued.
"Dame," he said, "so mot I the,
It sal noght so bifall of me; 1448 R sall.
For, sertes, I hete þe hardily
Þat tomorn my son sal dy; 1450 R sall.
Þan sal he neuer swilk dedes do." 1451 R sall.
Sho said: "Sir, God gif grace þarto." 1452 R Scho, gyf, þare to.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bigins þe Sext Prolong. Heading R bigyns, MS. vi.

LG.L: At morn sone efter þe son,
Þe Emperoure rase, als he was won; 1454 R Emperour rayse.
Into þe hal þan come he down; 1455 R hall, doune.
Þar was moni balde barown. 1456 R þare, many bold baroune.
Doun he settes him in his sete, 1457 R Doune.
And biddes his son fra preson fet; 1458 R bydes, fete.
And biliue þai sold be boun 1459 R bi lyue, suld, boune.
To graue him quik withowten town, 1460 R quyk with outen toune.
So þat he sold neuer here tell 1461 R suld.
Mare of his son, how it bifell. 1462 R More.
Forth þai led þe semly childe; 1463 R semely child.
Ladies weped and maidens milde, 1464 R Ladyse, maydens mylde.
So had þai sorow for to se
How he was led thurgh þat cete.
Right so come Maister Lentiliown, 1467 R Ryght, Lentilioune.
Rideand fast vnto þe toun, 1468 R Rydeand, toune.
Þat lered þe child are on þe boke.
For sorow he might noght on him loke; 1470 R myght, luke.
Bot forth he rides fast to þe hall, 1471 R rydes.
Omang þe knightes and swiers all, 1472 R knyghtes, squyers.
And on him fast þus gan þai cri: 1473 R cry.
"Maister, kith now þi maistri, 1474 R kyth, maistry.
And help þi scoler in þis nede." 1475 R scolere.
Þan to þe Emperoure he ȝede, 1476 R yhede.
And doun he knele[d] opon his kne. 1477 R doune, MS. knele.
Þe Emperoure wald noght on him se; 1478 R Emperour.
Til at þe last he said: "Traytoure, 1479 R Till.
God gif þe mekil misauentoure!" 1480 R gyf, mykell mysauentoure.
"A, lord," he said, "whi so? allas! 1481 R om. he said.
I am no traitur, saue ȝowre grace. 1482 R traytoure, yhour.
Ȝowre gentil wordes, lord, lat me here." 1483 R Yhour gentell.
He said: "Þou sal aby ful dere; 1484 R sall, full.
Þou and al þi cumpani 1485 R all, company.
Sal be drawen and hanged in hy. 1486 R Sall.
For I toke ȝow mi son to teche, 1487 R yhow my.
And ȝe haue gert him lose his speche, 1488 R yhe.
And also for to force my wife; 1489 R all so, wyfe.
Þarfore sal he lose his life." 1490 R þare of þarefor mutilated, sall, lyfe.
Þe maister said: "Sir, it war wrang 1491 R þe multilated.
Vs oþer to draw or hang; 1492 R outher.
And if þou do þi son forfare,
Þou sal haue shame als mekil or mare 1494 R sall, schame, mykell.
Als he had þat his wife gert take
With enimes for hir owin ded sake." 1496 R enmyse, awen dede.
Þe Emperoure said: "What was he? 1497 R Emperour.
Þat tale, maister, þou most tel me." 1498 R tell.
"What helpis to tel, sir, in þis stede, 1499 R helpes, tell.
And þi son þat tyme war dede?
Gif him respit, I þe pray, 1501 R Gyf, respyte, say after þe deleted.
Whils þat I my reson say."
Þe Emperoure him granted respite, 1503 R Emperour, graunted respyte.
And he was broght ogain ful tite. 1504 R ogayne full tyte.
And þan Maister Lentiliowne 1505 R Len∣tilyoune.
Blithli bigan his resown. 1506 R Blythely, resoune.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Sext Tale Sayd Maister Lentilion. Heading MS. vi., R said, Lentilioune. [Story VI. Puteus.]

LG.L: "Sir, whilum was in þis cuntre 1507 R Whilom, contre, þis in margin.
A riche man of gold and fe. 1508 R ryche, fee.
Hym wanted nothing bot a wife, 1509 R Him, wyfe.
For to solace with his life.
Of neghburs childer none wald he, 1511 R childre.
Bot toke a whife in strange cuntre; 1512 R wife, straunge contre.
A damisel he feched ferr; 1513 R damysell.
He might haue had wele better nere. 1514 R myght, nerr.
Faire sho was and lufsom als; 1515 R scho.
Bot vnderneth ȝit was sho fals; 1516 R yhit, scho.
Sho had a leman preuely 1517 R Scho, lemman.
Þat lang bifore had liggen her by. 1518 R lyggen hir.
When hir husband had broght hir home,
Hir leman smertly efter come. 1520 R lemman.
He toke a chamber nere þat stede. 1521 R chumbre.
Him thurt noght care þan for his brede;
Þe wife fand him inogh plente; 1523 R wyfe, I noghe.
With þe husband gode ful meri made he. 1524 R gud full mery.
And when þe wife might þeder wyn, 1525 R myght þider.
To play þam let þai for no sin. 1526 MS. let obliterated except for part of l, R lett, syn.
"In þat toun was ane vsage 1527 R toune, MS. w.. .ne.
Þat halden was with maister and page:
Þat whoso war tane in þe toun 1529 MS. w.. ...e, R toune.
Efter curfu bel vp or down, 1530 R After curfew, MS. be. .p, R bell, doune.
Seriantes sold þam tak ful sone 1531 R suld, full.
And hastily in preson done;
And on þe morn for ani thing 1533 R any.
Bifore domes-men þai sold him bring; 1534 R Bi for, suld, bryng.
Þan thorgh þe toun men sal þam driue. 1535 R thurgh, toune, sall, dryue.
Þe gudeman percayued of his wiue, 1536 R gud man, persayued, wyue.
How þat sho rase o nightes him fra 1537 R scho rayse o nyghtes.
And tald him noght wheder sho wold ga; 1538 MS. whedes, R whider scho wald.
Bot til hir leman went sho sone, 1539 R tyll, lem∣man, scho.
And come ogain when þe plai was done. 1540 R ogayne, play.
Þe gudeman had wonder of his wife, 1541 R gud man, wyfe.
And ful lath him was to strife; 1542 R full, stryfe.
Wele he thoght þar was sum gile, 1543 R þare, som gyle.
Bot ȝit he wold habide a while. 1544 R yhit, abyde.
"Opon a night þarefter sone 1545 R nyght þare efter.
To bed þai went, als þai war won. 1546 R wone.
Vntil his whif he turned his bak, 1547 R vn tyll, wife.
And still he lay and nothing spak. 1548 R styll.
When sho hopid he war on slepe, 1549 R scho hoped, was.
Þe whif out of þe bed gan crepe. 1550 R wife.
Þe gudeman wele percayued in hi 1551 R gud man, persayued, hy.
How þat sho went to hir lutby. 1552 R scho.
When he wist how þe gamin ferd, 1553 R gamen.
Þe dore ful stalworthly he sperd 1554 R full.
With lokkes and with barres grete,
And lete his whif stand in þe strete. 1556 R wyfe.
He sweres bi God, mekil of might, 1557 R mykell, myght.
Sho sold noght come þarin þat night. 1558 R Scho suld, com þare in, nyght.
Þe whif at þe dore þe ring gan shak; 1559 R wife, ryng, schake.
Þe godeman at a window spak, 1560 R gud man, wyndow spake.
And said: 'Now mai þou noght sai nay, 1561 R may, say.
How þou has done þis moni a day. 1562 R many.
Now haue I tane þe hand-haueing; 1563 R hand haueyng.
Þou may deny it for nothing.
Vnto þi fere ogain þou fare; 1565 R ogayn.
Þi cumpani kepe I na mare.' 1566 R company I kepe no.
"Sho said: 'Sir, merci for Ihesu! 1567 R Scho, mercy.
For right sone sal þai ring curfu. 1568 R ryght sone will, ryng.
If men me find, I mun be tane; 1569 R fynd, mon.
And leuere me war here to be slane.' 1570 R leuer.
'Nai, dame,' he said, 'so mot I the, 1571 R Nay.
In þi syn sal þou taken be; 1572 R sall.
Al þi kyn sal heren and sene 1573 R All, sall.
What myster woman þou has bene.'
"Sho saw hir prayer helpid noght, 1575 R Scho, helped.
Þan of a wile sho hir bythoght. 1576 R wyle scho, bi thoght.
Sho waited hir a heui stane 1577 R Scho wayted, heuy.
And said" 'Sertes or I here be tane,
Sir, þe soth I sal þe tell: 1579 R sall.
I sal me drown right in þis well.' 1580 R sall, drowne ryght.
'Dame, wheþer þou wil þe drown or hang, 1581 R will, droune.
Me think þou has lifed al to lang.' 1582 R lyfed all.
Þan preuely sho toke þe stane 1583 R scho.
And went vnto þe well onane.
'Sir,' sho said, 'vengance I call; 1585 R scho.
For in þis well now wil I fall.' 1586 R will.
Sho lete þe stane fal in þe well, 1587 R Scho, fall.
And stirt vnder a stok ful still. 1588 R styrt, full stell.
Þe godeman herd noys of þe stane; 1589 R gud man.
And þan he was ful wil of wane: 1590 R full will.
He wend his whif had fallen down 1591 R wyfe, doune.
Into þe well, hirself to drown. 1592 R droune.
'Allas,' he said, 'mi whif es ded!' 1593 R my wif, dede.
And forth he went ful wil of rede. 1594 R will.
He opind þe ȝates and went þareout, 1595 R opend, yhates.
And law into þe wel gan lowt. 1596 R well, lout.
"And whils he morned in þe gate, 1597 R murned.
Þe whif wan sone in at þe ȝate. 1598 R wife, yhate.
Þe dore sho sperres and barres fast 1599 R scho.
With barres þat ful wele wald last. 1600 R full.
Þe godeman heres þe dore sper hard, 1601 R gud man.
And fast he hies him þederward. 1602 R hyes, þiderward.
'Whannow?' he sayd, 'wha es þare now?' 1603 R said.
Þan went þe whif to a window; 1604 R wyfe, wyndow.
Sho said: 'What dose þou now þarout? 1605 R Scho.
Es it now time to walk obout?' 1606 R tyme.
"'A, dame,' he sayd, 'for luf of þe, 1607 R said.
For þat þou sold noght perist be!' 1608 R suld, peryst.
'Nay,' sho said, 'now am I here; 1609 R scho.
I haue no drede of þi dangere.' 1610 R dred, daungere.
'Lat me in, dame, I pray þe!'
'Nay,' sho said, 'so mot I the!' 1612 R scho.
'Ȝis, dame,' he said, 'for heuyn kyng, 1613 R Yhis, heuen.
For alsone wil men curfu ring.' 1614 R will, ryng.
'Ȝa,' sho said, 'þat es wele done, 1615 R Yha scho.
Þe wakemen sal þe tak ful sone, 1616 R sall, full.
And se þat þou has bene lichowre 1617 R lychoure.
And cumes hame efter curfoure. 1618 R comes.
Þe war fayrer hald with þi spouse 1619 R fairer.
Þan spend oure gude at þe hore-hows.' 1620 R our gud, hore howse.
"Þan come þe wakemen þar biside 1621 MS. wake man, R þare bysyde.
And herd þam twa togeder chide. 1622 R to gyder chyde.
Curfu bel was rungen þan, 1623 R Curfew bell, rongen.
Þarfore tane was þe gudeman. 1624 R þarfor, gud man.
Þai had grete ferly it so ferd, 1625 R gret.
For euil of him neuere are þai herd. 1626 R euell, neuer.
Þarfore þai prayed þe woman þare
To lat him in and speke na mare. 1628 R spek no.
Þan said þe whife maliciows: 1629 R wife maliciouse.
'He comes now fra þe hore-hows; 1630 R howre howse.
Þus has he oft-siþes serued me, 1631 R oft sythes.
And þarfore may we neuer the. 1632 R þarfor.
Ful lang haue I hid his shame; 1633 R ffull, hir schame.
Now sal himselues bere þe blame.' 1634 R sall him seluen.
"Þan vnto presown put he was. 1635 R presone putt.
Þe whife at hame had hir solas; 1636 R wife, solace.
For sone hir leman come hir till, 1637 R lemman, tyll.
And þai had mete and drink at will. 1638 R drynk.
At morn sone was þe gudeman fet 1639 R Att, gud man fett.
Bifor þe domes-men þat war set; 1640 R sett.
Thurgh þe toun þan was he led, 1641 R toune.
Fowl desspoyled and al uncled. 1642 R ffoule despoyled, all.
Seþin lathly haue þai led him hame. 1643 R Sithen lathely.
Þat whif was worthi for to blame 1644 R wife.
Þat lete þam so hir husband lede
Anly for hir awin mysdede; 1646 R Anely, awen.
Þis woman kouth of gile sumdele." 1647 R couth, gyle som dele.
"Ȝa, sertes," said þe Emperoure, "ful wele; 1648 R Yha, Emperour full.
Sho was wele wer þan ani hownd." 1649 R Scho, any hounde.
Þe maister said: "Swik fele er found.
And, sir, be ȝe noght euil payd, 1651 R yhe, euell payde.
Ȝowre awin es wer, war sho asaid. 1652 R Yhour awen, war war scho asayde.
And if þat þou, thurgh hir euil rede, 1653 R euell.
Gers þi son be done to ded, 1654 R Ger, dede.
Swilk shame mot þou haue in þi liue
Als had þis gudeman for his wiue." 1656 R gud man, wyue.
Þe Emperoure sayd: "Sir, for þi tale, 1657 R Emperour said.
Þis dai mi son sal haue no bale." 1658 R day my, sall.
Þe child was done into presoun, 1659 R presoune.
And þe maister went out of þe toun. 1660 R toune.
Vnto his felows he tald þe case, 1661 R felaws, þis.
How his decipil helpid was. 1662 R disciple helped wase.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bigyns Þe Seuind Prolong. Heading MS., R vii.

LG.L: Þe knightes voided out of þe towre; 1663 R knyghtes voyded, toure.
To chamber went þe Emperoure. 1664 R chaumbre.
He findes his whif þare makand sorow; 1665 R fyndes, wyfe.
Sho sais sho sal noght bide tomor[o]w. 1666 R Scho says scho sall, byde, MS. tomorw.
"Dame," he sayd, "whi sais þou so?" 1667 R said, says.
Sho said: "I ne mai none oþer do; 1668 R Scho, may.
For leuer me war oway be gane
Þan se þi landes fra þe tane. 1670 R fro.
Þi maisters to shame sal þe bring 1671 R schame sall, bryng.
With argumentes and with lesing. 1672 R lesyng.
Wele it semes for to be swa
Þat many sal speke of vs twa 1674 R sall.
Als did anes of a riche king 1675 R rych kyng.
And a steward and a lady ȝing." 1676 R yhing.
"How bifel þat, dame, tel me, 1677 R bi fell, tell.
Als þou wil þat I luf þe." 1678 R will.
Sho said: "My telling es noght worth, 1679 R Scho, tellyng.
For my reson may noght forth.
If I sai neuer so sothfastly, 1681 R say.
I se þou settes nothing þarby; 1682 R þare by.
And þarfore wil I hald me still, 1683 R þarfor will, styll.
What shame so þai will do þe till." 1684 R schame, tyll.
He said: "Dame, tel me þi resown, 1685 R tell, resoune, MS. reswon.
And sertanly I sal be boun 1686 R sertainly, sall, boune.
To do þi lyking al bidene." 1687 R lykyng all be dene.
Þe Emperice said: "Sir, now be sene."

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Seuind Tale Sayd þe Wife. Heading MS., R vii., R said, wyfe. [Story VII. Senescalcus.]

LG.L: "Syr," sho said, "þis ender ȝere 1689 R Sir scho, yhere.
Was a king of grete powere; 1690 R kyng, gret.
Bath Poyle and Calaber land 1691 R Both.
Was halely bowand to his hand. 1692 R tyll.
But in luf had he no delite; 1693 R delyte.
He vsed no wemen brown ne quite; 1694 R wemman browne, white.
Til at þe last þe riche king 1695 R Till, rych kyng.
On his members had bolnyng, 1696 R membirs.
Þat þe skin might noght ouer it reche; 1697 R skyn myght.
And sone he sent to seke a leche. 1699 R with outen lettyng.
And when he come, without letting
Was he broght bifor þe kyng.
He gert þe king sone make vrine, 1701 R kyng, vryne.
To loke what might be his medcine; 1702 R luke, myght, medcyne.
Þat þe king might lif wele saw he þare. 1703 R kyng myght lyf.
A plaster he layd vnto þe sare; 1704 R laid.
He made him medcines moni and sere, 1705 R medcyns many.
Vntil þe king was hale and fere. 1706 R vn tyll, kyng.
Þe leche said: 'Sir, for þi bote
On al maner nedes þou mote 1708 R manere.
Have wemen to play with o night; 1709 R wemmen, o nyght.
Þan sal ȝe sone be helid right.'
Þe king said: 'Right so I sall'; 1711 R kyng.
And sone his steward gert he call.
"Þe steward said: 'Sir, what wil ȝe?' 1713 R will yhe.
'A leman,' he said, 'feche þou me, 1714 R lemman.
Þat I mai þis night with hir play 1715 R may, nyght.
And mak me mirth al þat I may.' 1716 R myrth all.
'Sir,' said þe steward, 'bi Saint Iohn,
In þis cuntre knaw I none 1718 R contre.
Þat wald be with ȝow in bed; 1719 R yhow.
For ȝowre word so wide es spred.' 1720 R yhour worde, wyde.
Þe king said: 'Hete hir hardily 1721 R kyng.
Ten pownd of gold to lig me by.' 1722 R pound, lyg.
'Sir,' said þe steward, 'it sal be done.' 1723 R sall.
Hame he hied him þan ful sone, 1724 R hyed, full.
And fol oft thinkes þe steward þan: 1725 R full.
'I wald I war a faire woman, 1726 R fair.
So þat I might win þis golde, 1727 R myght wyn, gold.
And do þarwith what I wolde.' 1728 R þare with, wold.
Þe steward was so couaitus, 1729 R couetus.
He said: 'Þe gold sal go with vs.' 1730 R suld ga.
"Vntil his wife he went onane 1731 R Vn till.
And said: 'Þou most an erand gane.' 1732 R ane.
'Gladly,' sho said, 'sir; telles me wheder.' 1733 R scho, whider.
'Þe king es seke, þou most go þeder 1734 R kyng, þider.
For to play with him þis night; 1735 R nyght.
Ten pound of gold he has þe hight.
Þis night þou do what he wil craue; 1737 R nyght, will.
Þat gold, dame, þan sal we haue.' 1738 R sall.
'A, sir,' sho said, 'lattes be, fy! fy! 1739 R scho.
He is noght lufsom to lig by, 1740 R lyg.
And þat wate mani woman wele; 1741 R many wemen.
Þat war hard winyng of catele.' 1742 R wynyng.
He said: 'Þou sal lig þare þis night 1743 R sall lyg, nyght.
For þe gold þat he has hight;
For he that nothing win will,
Nedely moste he lose bi scill. 1746 R most, skyll.
And, dame, þis gold now sal þou win, 1747 R sall, wyn.
Or I sal cache þe fro mine in.' 1748 R sall, myne.
"Sho said: 'Sen I mot nedes þartill, 1749 R Scho, most, þar tyll.
God wote at it es noght my will.' 1750 R þat.
Þe steward wald noght dwel ful lang; 1751 R dwell.
He gert his whif forth with him gang, 1752 R wife.
And hastily he has hir led
Right bifore þe kinges bed. 1754 R bi for, kynges.
He did out torches al bidene, 1755 R all.
For no man sold his whif sene; 1756 R suld, wife.
And þan he gert his owin whife 1757 R awen wyfe.
Go to þe kinges bed with strif. 1758 R kynges, stryfe.
Þan till his owin bed he went. 1759 R till, awen.
Þe king þe lady in armes hent; 1760 R kyng.
Of hir was he right wele paid, 1761 R ryght, payd.
And at his will with hir he plaid. 1762 R playd.
"Þe steward nothing slepe might; 1763 R myght.
He sighed and sorowd al þat night. 1764 R syghed, sorowed all, nyght.
Sone on þe morn, when it was day,
To þe kinges chamber he toke þe wai. 1766 R kynges chaumbre, way, MS. chanber.
Þe kyng lay ful wele and warm, 1767 R full, warme.
Slepeand in þe ladies arm. 1768 R Slepand, ladyes arme.
Þe steward had ful mekil wa; 1769 R full mykell.
Vp and doun fast gan he ga,
And sighed euer with mekil sorow 1771 R syghed, mykell.
Vntil it was nere myd-morow. 1772 R vn tyll.
Þe king sleped ful wele ay; 1773 R kyng, full.
Þe steward thoght ful lang þai lay. 1774 R full.
'Allas!' he said, 'I was to blame
To do myself so mekil schame. 1776 R mykell.
Better es to waken þe king 1777 R kyng.
And preueli my whif hame bring.' 1778 R preuely, wife, bryng.
He opind þe chamber dor bilyue 1779 R opend, chaumbre dore.
Whare þe king lay with his wyue; 1780 R kyng.
'Wake, sir,' he said, 'it es forth dais; 1781 R days.
And lattes þe lady wend hir waies.' 1782 R ways.
"'Nai,' said þe king, 'by Saint Dinise, 1783 R Nay, kyng be, Dynyse.
Ȝit ne think I noght to rise; 1784 R Yhit, ryse.
First, in faith, I sal asay 1785 R ffirst, fayth, sall assay.
With þis lady anes to play.'
'Nai, sir,' he sayd, 'for, sertanly, 1787 R Nay, said, sertainly.
Þat es my whif þat ligges þe by.' 1788 R wife, lygges yhow.
'What!' said þe king, 'es þis þi whif?' 1789 R kyng, wife.
Þe steward said: 'Ȝa, bi mi life!' 1790 R yha, my lyfe.
'Fy!' said þe king, 'fitz de putayne! 1791 R kyng fytz.
Whi lete þou hir þan be forlayne?'
Þe steward said: 'Sir, for ten pownd 1793 R pound.
Of florins þat er riche and rownd.' 1794 R florance, ryche, round.
Þe king said: 'Þou wate ful wele, 1795 R kyng, full.
I bad þe bring a damysele 1796 R bryng.
And noght to bring to me þi wiue; 1797 R bryng, wyue.
Out of my land þou fle bilyue! 1798 R be lyue.
Þou has bitraied þi whif and me. 1799 R bitrayd, wif.
And þou bide til I resin be, 1800 R byde tyll rysen, omitting I.
I sal ger draw þi traytur cors 1801 R sall.
Thurgh þis toun with wild hors! 1802 R toune, wyld.
Out of my land I fleme þe,
And þi whif sal won with me. 1804 R wife sall.
If þou habide mine vp-rising, 1805 R habyde my vp ryseyng.
Þou sal be hanged, by heuyn king!' 1806 R sall, bi heuen kyng.
Þusgat þe steward lost his whife, 1807 R þusgate, wyfe.

Euer sho cried and made murning. 2862 MS. shied, R scho cryed, mornyng.
Hir frendes went oway ilkane,
And þus þe lady leued allane.
"Þat ilk day war outlaws thre 2865 R outlawes.
Dampned and hanged on galow tre,
And knightes war þai euerilkane. 2867 R knyghtes.
Ful many had þai robbed and slane; 2868 R ffull, MS. Robbed.
Þarfore war þai hastily hent, 2869 R And þarfor.
And hanged so by right iugement. 2870 R bi ryght.
Anoþer knyght of þat cuntre 2871 R Ane other, contre.
Fel for to kepe þa theues thre 2872 R ffell.
On þe galows al þat nyght, 2873 R all.
Als it was resown and right. 2874 R resowne, ryght.
For, sirs, ȝe sal wele vnderstand, 2875 R yhe sall.
He gaf na ferm els for his land 2876 R no.
Bot for to kepe þe galows a night 2877 R nyght.
When þare hang gentel men or knight; 2878 R gentyll man, knyght.
And if ani þan war oway, 2879 R any.
His landes sold he lose for ay. 2880 R suld.
"Þe knight him cled in nobil wede, 2881 R knyght, nobyll.
And set him on a stalworth stede, 2882 R sett.
And went to kepe þe knightes thre 2883 R knyghtes.
Þat hanged on þe galow tre. 2884 R hynged.
Þe frost fresed fast þarout; 2885 R [þe fros]t frecsed, þare out.
Þe knight rides euer obout, 2886 R [þe k]nyght rydes.
Biside þe galows vp and down, 2887 R .. syde, doune.
So was he dredand of tresown. 2888 R tresoune.
So grete cald come him vnto 2889 R gret.
Þat he ne wist what he might do. 2890 R myght.
Toward þe toun luked þe knyght; 2891 R toune loked.
He saw a fire brin faire and bright 2892 R fyre bryn fair, bryght.
In þe kirk-ȝerd of þe town; 2893 R kyrk yherd, toune.
And þeder fast he made hym boun. 2894 R þider, him boune.
Vnto þe loge he come onane;
Þe lady þare he fyndes allane.
To cal and speke wald he noght spare. 2897 R call, spek.
Þe lady sais sone: 'Wha es þare?'
'I am a knyght þat wald me warm, 2899 R warme.
And wend my way withowten harm.' 2900 R with outen harme.
Þe lady said: 'By him me boght, 2901 R be.
Herin, sir, ne cumes þou noght!' 2902 R Here in, comes.
'Lat me cum in, dame, I þe pray.' 2903 R com.
Þe lady said ful sadly: 'Nay.' 2904 R full.
'A, dame,' he said, 'me es ful kalde; 2905 R full cald.
A litel while wharm me I walde.' 2906 R lytell, warme, wald.
'Sir,' sho said, 'bi him me boght, 2907 R scho
In þis close ne cumes þou noght!' 2908 R Here in sir ne comes.
'A, dame,' he said, 'par charyte,
Þare sal na man wit bot we.' 2910 R sall, witt.
Þe knyght spak so with þe lady
Þat in he come and sat hir by, 2912 R satt.
And warmed him wele at his will.
Þe lady gret and gaf hir ill. 2914 R grett.
"Þan said þe knight to hir in hy: 2915 R knyght.
'Dame, whi ertou so sary, 2916 R ertow.
And whi ertou þus here allane, 2917 R ertow.
And so with murning makes þi mane? 2918 R mornyng.
Tel me, gude dame, I þe pray, 2919 R Tell, gud.
And I sal help þe if I may.' 2920 R sall.
Sho said: 'Sir, I am wil of rede, 2921 R Scho, will.
For my lord es fra me dede,
And right here es he laid in graue; 2923 R ryght, layd.
Swilk a lord mun I neuer haue; 2924 R mon.
He lufed me euer ful stedfastly: 2925 R full.
Þarfore here wil I lif and dy.' 2926 R þarfor, will, lyf.
"Þe knyght said: 'Dame, þou ert a fole
Þat þou makes so mekyl dole. 2928 R mykell.
What helpes it so to sorow þe
For thing þat may noght mended be?
Þiseluen mai þou so forfare, 2931 R may.
And him ogayn gettes þou na mare. 2932 R getes, no.
I rede þou morn na mare þarfore; 2933 R red, no.
Þou may haue ane worth twenti score. 2934 R twenty.
Þarfore, dame, do efter me, 2935 R þarfor.
And lat now al þi murning be; 2936 R latt, all, mornyng.
I rede þou luf som oþer knyght 2937 R red.
Þat may þe cumforth day and night.' 2938 R comforth, nyght.
'Nay,' sho said, 'sir, by Saint Iohn, 2939 R scho, Iohan.
Swilk a lord get I neuer none 2940 R gett.
Þat so mekil wil mensk me, 2941 R mykell will.
Ne suffer my will als did he.
For to seke fra hethin till Ynde 2943 R fro.
Swilk a lord sold I neuer finde.' 2944 R suld, fynde.
"When þe knight had warmed him a while, 2945 R knyght.
He dred þat men sold do him gile, 2946 R suld, gyle.
To stele som of þe hanged men,
And ger him lose his landes þen.
He toke his leue of þe lady,
And went to his hors hastily.
Vnto þe galows rides he; 2951 R rydes.
And sone he myssed ane of þe thre.
Þan was þe knyght ful sary man; 2953 R full.
He hopid to tyne his landes ilkane. 2954 R hoped.
He thoght wemen kowth gif gud rede 2955 R couth gyf.
Vnto men þat had grete nede. 2956 R gret.
He was noght fer fro þe lady;
Ogayn he rides ful hastily. 2958 R Ogayne, rydes full.
He cald als he bifore had done, 2959 R be fore.
And in þan was he laten sone.
He said he had more sorow þan sho, 2961 R scho.
And assed wat was best to do. 2962 R asked what.
Al þe soth he gan hir say 2963 R All.
How his o knight was stollen oway. 2964 R knyght.
"Þan spak þe lady to þe knight: 2965 R knyght.
'Say me þe soth, sir, if þou myght,
If þou has any whif at hame?' 2967 R haue, wife.
'Nay,' he said, 'by swete Saint Iame, 2968 R be.
Whif ne leman had I neuer.' 2969 R Wife, lemman.
'Sir,' sho said, 'so es me leuyr; 2970 R scho, leuer.
Ful wele sal þou helped be, 2971 R ffull, sall.
If þat þou wil wed me.' 2972 R will.
'Ȝis, dame,' he said, 'by swete Ihesus!' 2973 R Yhis, be.
When þai had made þaire cownand þus, 2974 R conand.
'Sir, tak we vp þis cors,' sho sayd,— 2975 R scho said.
'Þis ilk day here was he layd,—
And hang him vp for him þat failes.' 2977 R hyng, fayles.
Þe knight was paid of þir counsailes: 2978 R knyght, payd, hir counsayles.
Out of þe graue þai toke þe cors;
Þe knight him led opon his hors. 2980 R knyght.
Þan said þe knyght to hir in hy:
'Dame, þou most hang him sertanli; 2982 R sertainly.
For if þat I hanged a knight, 2983 R hynged, knyght.
Mine honore war lorn by þat vnright.' 2984 R My honoure, bi, vnryght.
"Þe lady said: 'So haue I sele,
I sal hang hym wonder wele.' 2986 R sall, him.
Sho did þe rape obout his hals; 2987 R Scho dyd.
In hir faith sho was ful fals; 2988 R fayth scho, full.
Sho drogh him vp and fest him fast. 2989 R Scho.
'Lo,' sho said, 'now sal þis last.' 2990 R scho, sall.
'Dame,' said þe knight, 'habide a stound: 2991 R knyght habyde, stounde.
He þat here hanged had a wonde, 2992 R hynged, wounde.
In þe forheuyd wele to knaw; 2993 R forheued.
Swilkane on þis byhoues vs shaw, 2994 R bi houes, schaw.
Or els tomorn, in lytel while, 2995 R lytell.
Wil be percayued al oure gile.' 2996 R Will, persayued all our gyle.
'Sir,' sho said, 'draw owt þi swerde; 2997 R scho, out, swerd.
To smite him thar þe noght be fered. 2998 R smyte, ferd, MS. lered.
Smite my lord wharesom þe list. 2999 R Smyte, lyst.
Þan sal noght þi man be mist.' 3000 R sall, myst.
'Nay, dame,' he said, 'for al þis rike 3001 R all, ryke.
A ded knyght wald I noght strike.' 3002 R stryke.
Sho said: 'Tak me þi swerd þe fra, 3003 R Scho.
And I sal merk him or we ga.' 3004 R sall.
He tald hir whare þat sho sold smyte, 3005 R scho suld.
And on þe heuyd sho hit him tite. 3006 R heued scho hytt, tyte.
"Þan þe knyght wele vnderstode
Þat sho was cumen of vnkind blode. 3008 R scho, comen, vnkynd.
'Dame,' he said, 'by heuen rike, 3009 R be, ryke.
Ȝit es noght þis þat oþer lyke; 3010 R Yhit, þe tother.
His forteth war al smeten out.' 3011 R all smyten.
'Sir,' sho said, 'þarof no dowt; 3012 R scho, þare of na dout.
Smites out his teth, biliue, lat se.' 3013 R Smytes, bi lyue.
'Nay, dame,' he said, 'so mot I the,
I wil do him no velany; 3015 R will, vilany.
He was a knyght, and so am I.'
Þan þe whif sone toke a stane 3017 R wife.
And smate his fortheth out ilkane. 3018 R forteth.
When sho had on þis wise done, 3019 R scho.
Sho said vnto þe knight ful sone: 3020 R Scho, knyght full.
'Sir, now sal þou wed me.' 3021 R sall.
'Nay, dame,' he sayd, 'so mot I the! 3022 R said.
Are wald I swere to wed na wife, 3023 R wyfe.
Or I with þe sold lede my lyfe; 3024 R suld.
For þou wald hang me with a cord,
Right als þou has done þi lord.
Swilk sorow has þou shewed me now 3027 R schewed.
Þat I sal neuer no wemen trow.'"
Þan said þe maister to þe Emperowre: 3029 R Emperoure.
"I pray Ihesu, our Sauiowre, 3030 R our sauyoure.
Þat to þe fal slike velany 3031 R fall swilk vilany.
Als did þis knyght of his lady,
If þou for kownsail of þi whife 3033 R counsail, wyfe.
Reues þi faire son his life. 3034 R Reue, fair, lyfe.
Spare him, sir, vntil tomorow;
Vnto hir sal fal al þe sorow. 3036 R sall fall all.
For, sertes, sir, þi son sall speke;
By righ[t]wis dome þan þou him wreke." 3038 MS. righwisdome, R Bi ryghtwis dome þou sall.
Þe Emperoure said: "So mot I gang, 3039 R Emperour.
And I mai wit wha haues þe wrang, 3040 R may witt.
And wha þe right, sir, þan sal I 3041 R ryght, sall.
Deme þam bath ful rightwisly." 3042 R full ryghtwisly.
Þan þe mayster went hys way. 3043 R maister, his.
Þus was þe clerk saued þat day.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bygins þe Threttende Prolong.

LG.L: When it was þe tyme of nyght,
Þe Emperoure to bed hym dyght. 3046 R him.
Þe Emperice als went him tyll;
No word sho said, bot held hir still; 3048 R scho, styll.
And al night thoght sho by what rede 3049 R all nyght, scho be.
Þat sho myght ger þe child be dede. 3050 R scho.
On þe morn, when day was lyght,
Þe Emperoure rase vp ful right. 3052 R Emperour rayse, full ryght.
Sho saw he wald no langer ly, 3053 R Scho.
And vp sho rase ful hastyly. 3054 R scho rayse full hastily.
Sho vmbithoght hir of a gyn, 3055 R Scho vm by thoght.
How þat sho might best bigyn. 3056 R scho myght.
Sho said: "Sir, herd ȝe neuer þe geste, 3057 R Scho, yhe.
Why men makes þe foles feste?" 3058 R Whi.
"Na, dame," he said, "so mot I the!
If þou it wate, tel it to me." 3060-2 R mutilated for first four, three, and one letters respectively. 3060 R tell.
"Sir," sho said, "with ful gude chere; 3061 R scho, full gud.
A nobil tale here sal ȝe here." 3062 R noble, sall yhe.

DIV2.HEAD: Þe Threttende Tale Said þe Wyfe. [Story XIII. Roma.]

LG.L: "Þis cete, sir, withowten dout, 3063 R with outen.
Was sumtyme enseged obout, 3064 R som tyme.
With seuyn hathen kinges dai and night, 3065 R seuen, kynges day, nyght.
For to wyn yt if þai myght. 3066 R it.
Þai made ful mani asautes fell; 3067 R full many.
Al Cristendom þai thoght to quell. 3068 R All.
Þe Romaynes þat might wapen welde, 3069 R Romayns, weld.
Defended þam with spere and shelde;
Þe walles ful hardily þai held, 3071 R full.
And mani hathen folk þai feld. 3072 R many.
Bot of þe Sarezins had þai dowt 3073 R sarezyns, dout.
Þat nane durst pas þe ȝates without. 3074 R pass, yhates.
An old man þan, of grete honoure, 3075 R Ane, gret.
Spak vnto þe Emperoure:
'Sir, and þou wil do efter me, 3077 R will.
A gude cownsail I sal tel þe, 3078 R gud counsail, sall tell.
To save þis cete and þi men.'
Þe Emperoure said: 'Þat wald I ken.' 3080 R Emperour.
'To seuyn clerkes, sir, takes þis toun, 3081 R seuen, toune.
To ȝeme it fra destrucciowne,— 3082 R yheme, destruccioune.
O payn to lose þaire lyves all 3083 R þair.
If any faut to þis toun fall.' 3084 R toune.
"Þe Emperoure þan þe toun gan take 3085 R Emperour, toune.
To seuyn maisters at kepe and wake. 3086 R seuen.
A moneth þai it ȝemed wele, 3087 R yhemed.
So þat no man faut might fele. 3088 R myght.
When it come to þe moneth end,
Þai might no lenger it defend.
Þan ordand þai a fayre quayntise; 3091 R ordaind, fair quayntyse.
Herkin, sir, on whatkin wise. 3092 R Herken, whatkyn wyse.
Lenger might þai noght wele last, 3093 R myght.
For þaire vetayles failed fast; 3094 R þair vetailes faylest.
Þarfore þai ordand, by þaire wit,
How þat þai might best be quit. 3096 R myght, quytt.
"Ane of þa clerkes hight Genus; 3097 R hyght.
He was ful quaynt and cautelus; 3098 R full.
And efter him es named Ienuere,
Þat es a moneth of þe ȝere.
A garment to him gert he mak, 3101 R make.
Side and wide and wonder blak. 3102 R Syde, wyde, blake.
He gert it dub, fra top til to, 3103 R till.
With swerel tailes ful blak also. 3104 R swerell tayles full, all so.
Þan gert he ordain a vesere 3105 R ordaine, visere.
With twa faces and fowl of chere, 3106 R foule.
With lang noses and mowthes wide, 3107 R mouthes wyde.
And vgly eres on aiþer syde; 3108 W other, R ayther.
With eghen þat war ful bright and clere, 3109 R full bryght.
And brade ilkone als a sawsere;
With brade tonges and bright glowand, 3111 R bryght.
Als it war a fire-brand.
"When he had on þis wise done,
Þe folk of Rome he sembled sone,
And bad þam fast, withouten fayl, 3115 R fayle.
Ordain þam vnto batayl. 3116 R Ordaine, batayle.
Al þai answerd him vntil, 3117 R All, vntyll.
Þai sold be redy at his will, 3118 R suld.
On þe morn, with sheld and spere. 3119 R scheld.
Þe maister þan dyd on his gere,
And went vp in a towre on hight, 3121 R in till a toure.
Whare þe Sarzins se him myght. 3122 R sarezyns.
His veser on his heued he kest; 3123 R visere.
A bright merure oboune he fest; 3124 R bryght meroure, W aboue.
Twa swerdes out gan he brayd, 3125 R brayde.
And grete strakes obowt him laid. 3126 R gret, o bout, layde.
He made als mekil dyn and boste 3127 R mykell.
Als he had foghten ogayns an ost. 3128 R ane oste.
"When þe Sarsins saw þis meruail, 3129 R sarezyns, meruaile.
Þai wald no lenger bede batayl. 3130 R bataile.
Sum wend for þe merure lyght, 3131 R Som, meroure.
Þat it war ane angel bright, 3132 R aungell bryght.
Þat God had sent þeder, perchance, 3133 R þider per∣chaunce.
On þam for to tak vengance. 3134 R vengaune.
So mekil light þe merure kast 3135 R mykell lyght, meroure.
Þat þe Sarzins fled ful fast. 3136 R sarezyns, full.
Þe maister made slike nois omell, 3137 R slyke noys.
Sum hoped he war þe fend of hell. 3138 R Som, fende.
Þai war so temped in þat tyde,
Þare þai durst no lenger bide. 3140 R byde.
Þai opind þan þe ȝates of Rome, 3141 R opend, yhates.
And Cristend men fast efter come.
Þe Emperowre and his men ilkane 3143 R Emperour.
Of þe Sarezins slogh gode wane; 3144 R sarezyns þus slogh gud.
Als mani als þai might ouertake, 3145 R many, myght.
Fast þai gan þaire crownes crake. 3146 W gain, R crounes.
Þare wan þe Cristenmen honowre, 3147 R honoure.
And mekil gold and gude armowre. 3148 R mykell, gud armoure.
Þusgat Genus, þat was wise, 3149 R þusgate, wyse, W Gemis.
Wan þe maystri by quaintise. 3150 R maistri be quayntyse.
"Þe maysters of Rome and buriayse 3151 R maisters.
Said he was worthi to prayse;
And none was so worthy als he 3153 W om. was, R worthi.
Emperoure of Rome to be. 3154 R Emperour.
And right so, by þaire aller dome, 3155 R ryght, þair.
Þai made him Emperoure of Rome. 3156 R Emperour.
"Sir, þus sall þi maisters wise
Decayue þe with þaire quayntise; 3158 R Desayue, þair quayntyse.
And þou mun be ful fayn, may fall, 3159 R mon, full fayne.
On knese for to serue þam all.
I prai to God it might be so, 3161 R pray, myght.
If þou more traystes þam vnto; 3162 R trayst more.
For þai er nothing els obout
Bot to mak þe þaire vnderlout. 3164 W, R make, R þair.
Þat sal men se ful sone, I trow, 3165 R sall, full.
And þiself sal noght wit how 3166 R sall, wytt.
Vntil þou lose al þine honowre, 3167 R vn tyll, all, honoure.
And sum of þam be Emperoure. 3168 R som.
Ȝit war me leuere þat þai so ware 3169 R Yhit.
Þan þi son þat greues me sare."
Þus when þe Emperoure herd hir speke,
He said als swith he sold hir wreke, 3172 R swyth, suld.
And alsone sold his son be slayn. 3173 R als sone suld, slayne, W sone.
Sho thanked him and was ful fayn. 3174 R Scho, full fayne.
Þan out of chamber gan þai pas. 3175 R chaumbre.
Þus hir tale endid sho has. 3176 R ended scho.

DIV2.HEAD: Here Bygins Þe Fourtend Prolong. Heading W om., R bigyns, MS., R xiiii.

LG.L: Þe Emperoure þan went to hall.
His turmentowres son gert he call; 3178 R turmentoure sone.
He bad þai sold let for nothing 3179 R suld lett.
His son with scowrges for to dyng; 3180 R skourges.
And when þat þai had sogates done, 3181 R sogate.
He bad he sold be hanged sone:— 3182 R suld, W honged.
"So þat I na more him se, 3183 R no.
For mekil meneyng makes he me." 3184 R ffull mykell.
Þe childe þan out of þe toun þai led, 3185 R child, toune.
So forbeten þat he bled.
And right als þai went with him þus, 3187 R ryght.
So come Maister Maxencius. 3188 W com.
He sese his scolere him bisyde;
He prays þe folk a while to byde.
A while þai hight to dwel þare still; 3191 R dwell, sty...
Þe toun ful fast he hies him till. 3192 R toune full, hyes, tyll.
He come bifore þe Emperoure, 3193 R bi for.
And hailsed him with grete honowre. 3194 R haylsed, gret honoure.
He sayd: "Sir, þou ert hy iustise; 3195 R said, hegh iustyse.
Þe aght wele to be war and wise.
Me think þou wirkis to þi reproue 3197 R wirkes.
Onence þi son, þat þou sold loue. 3198 R suld.
For a day wiltou be his frende, 3199 R will þou.
Anoþer day þou wil him shende. 3200 R Ane other, will, schende, W wilt.
Al day mai men turn þi mode; 3201 R All, may.
So fares foles þat can na gode, 3202 R kan, W, R no, R gude.
And namly þai þat dose þaire dede 3203 R namely, þair.
Als wikked wemen wil þam rede. 3204 R wicked, will.
Þou trowes ouer wele þi wiues tale,
Þat es obout to brew þe bale.
If þi son til tomorn may lif, 3207 R till, lyf.
For nankins gode þou wald him gif. 3208 R nanekyng gud, gyf.
And if þou by þi wyues rede 3209 R do instead of by, wyfe, W wiues.
Ger do þi son to euil dede,
Swilk a chance mot fal to þe 3211 R chaunce, fall.
Als did ane erl of þis cuntre. 3212 R dyd, erell, contre.
He trowed mare of his wife a leghe 3213 R legh.
Þan þat himself saw with his eghe." 3214 R egh.
Þe Emperoure sayd: "Me think wele þan 3215 R said.
Þat he was no witty man,
Þat his whife wordes trowed sold be 3217 R wife, suld, W he for be.
Better þan þat himself might se." 3218 R myght.
"Sir," sayd þe maister, "so ertow; 3219 R said.
For þi whif tales wil þou trow 3220 R wife, will.
Better þan any oþer rede;
And sho wald ger þi son be ded. 3222 R scho, dede.
And if he haue þis day respite, 3223 R respyte.
Tomorn he sal himseluen quite. 3224 R sall, quyte.
Þan sal þou þiseluen se 3225 R sall, þi self.
Wha haues þe wrang, þi wife or he." 3226 W haue.
